author: HikerCZ
title: The VIP treatment
review:
As a regular VIP customer I felt obliged to get the latest freebie. Even though getting it is not that easy this time around, you have to spend a substantial amount of money to get it. 

First surprise - it comes in a polyethylene bag not a box (probably to keep the production cost lower). Second surprise - it's quite heavy and when you pile the bricks, it feels like a regular small to medium retail set.

The build starts promisingly and it's fairly simple. You have to be extra careful to align all those 1x1s but it's doable. A brick separator (not included) will do the trick. One possible drawback (for me) are the stickers. I am one of those strange fellows who adamantly refuses to apply stickers no matter how important they seem. And in a set where stickers represent Lego boxes in a shop that's a real bummer. Without the stickers you just have a bunch of colourful tiles on a wall and it looks quite dull to be honest. 

Another drawback becomes obvious when you finish the VIP 'wall' and connect it to the shop structure. They look disjointed. I've raised the shop section by one brick to make it the same height as the VIP wall and it looks much better. That said you can always keep the two sections separate. The VIP wall is luckily able to stand by itself without any additional supports. 

Two figures are included, one monochromatic red for the VIP part and a shop assistant with an exclusive (?) torso, which is probably the best feature of this set.  

All in all it's a nice little thing (especially the shop) with lovely references all regular brick and mortar customers recognise. For those who aren't that lucky to have a genuine Lego store in their country (mine included), it's a chance to own something rather unique and special. And of course it's for free, which is never wrong. After building it and looking at it, I wouldn't probably spend my money on this set, however, as a freebie it's perfectly recommendable.

author: Odeinoichus
title: An Exclusive bit of Fun for VIP Members.
review:
Set #40178 VIP Set: LEGO had this on offer as a free giveaway to commemorate something or other, honestly I’ve kind of forgotten what, but it was a great idea as it offered some really fun models for folks to build and display as part of their LEGO collection. Only VIP members were given this set, if you were not a VIP member you could not receive it. Unfortunate for folks which wanted it, however it makes sense, from a business standpoint. It was also limited to one-per-household as far as I recall, they only offered it once and if you ordered another order later on that month it would omit the free item… I could be wrong on that, but from my personal experience it was only one per customer.

Packaging

A specialized Polybag was designed to house the set, this may have resulted in certain white elements prematurely yellowing slightly due to the nature of the plastic polybag, as the bag in question was not the typical material used for Polybags. Some of the white elements on my set do look as though they are slightly more yellowish than white, though it is marginally noticeable unless exposed in direct light. However I feel it important to mention this, and I opened it as soon as I got it, so… the longer it stays in the package the worse it may develop.

The instructions are typical for LEGO sets of this sort, not much to say about this as with most promotional items there aren’t any cross-promotional images to be found. Stickers were also included for the details on certain elements.

Parts

This set featured primarily regular parts, a lot of white tiles and plates, which as noted may suffer premature yellowing due to the nature of the plastic bag used to package them. Which is a shame as there were four plain white watermelon tiles included in the set, as well as two red versions. It may not be best as a parts pack due to the problematic packaging situation, but the set does feature a nice array of LEGO elements.

Minifigures

LEGO Store Employee: The only unique element for this Minifigure is the torso which features the LEGO logo on the back and a nametag on the front which is blank. I am a huge fan of characters like this, real-world equivalents in the LEGO universe, he’s great and a very nice addition to the set.

VIP Monofigure: A Mono-Figure was included for the “I” in VIP just like with the design on the cards, this is great if you’re looking for Mono-Figures to collect.

The build

With this set you build a LEGO store, a very small alcove-like LEGO store and a massive VIP card in LEGO form. The VIP card build is very SNOT heavy with a load of tiles used to hide the studs. The LEGO store build incorporates a lot of fine detail work as you build a very nice looking final end product which features a load of detailing. There is a modular element involved with some Technic pins to connect the two models once finished, the build itself was extremely satisfying though, despite the small nature of the model.

The completed model

The LEGO Store is very detail oriented, with stickers used on tiles to represent actual LEGO sets, the sets depicted include two Juniors sets, one of them from Ninjago the other which looks like the Marvel Spider-Man Juniors set with the helicopter, a LEGO City set which I believe was the Tire Escape set, the LEGO Friends Hot Dog vehicle, the LEGO Ghostbusters Firehouse HQ and what I believe is a LEGO Creator set and a LEGO DUPLO set though I could be wrong about that.

The back wall is the Pick and Build wall complete with a sticker and colored studs covered by headlight studs to show the various parts you can pick and build with. The cash register is included and that bin thing in the front of the store where bricks are kept for younger fans during build events… I have no idea what the official name is as I do not have any younger builders in the house to participate in such events.

For store displays you have a Red 2x4 brick in the front and a buildable dragon that I believe is quite popular in Europe. The name escapes me at the moment, it’s been a while since I checked out other reviews of the set, and being in Canada this particular display is not included in my local LEGO store.

The VIP Card is pretty much what you’d expect, a LEGO VIP card built out of bricks. Do not try and use this at the store though, it, uh, won’t work. LOL The modular pin connectors help out a lot, if you wanted you could MOC up a much larger store and connect them together with the pins while keeping the VIP card perhaps as a back wall for the store, since it can be connected to for both of you.

Overall opinion

This is a pretty great freebie. Some folks have complained that the LEGO Store portion is a bit on the small side, but such places do exist, smaller outlets should be represented as well and for folks who would like to have a LEGO store in their display this is the next best thing as the official LEGO Store set is impossible to get unless you go on opening day for a new LEGO Store.

Would I recommend this on the secondary market? It depends on a few key factors, if you would like to have this particular set, or the LEGO VIP card it might be easier to bricklink most of the parts. However, keep in mind that if you want this actual set the packaging may be causing a premature yellowing effect on the white elements. With all of this in mind I would recommend it if you absolutely have to have it and missed out during the giveaway time. However you can safely skip it if you aren’t interested in this type of set.

author: alfred_the_buttler
title: Absolute bargain for your VIP points
review:
So the new VIP program allows you to get this for 500 points. Considering that it takes 650 points to get $5 off, that mean this set effectively costs less than $4. However, you still need to pay for shipping if you don’t reach the minimum $35 for free shipping, and after redeeming your points, you only have 30 days to order this set. 

The brick count for the set is a little misleading. Yes, it does have all the pieces it says, but this is a small highly detailed set so that means tons of small bricks. The pick a brick wall alone is composed of 12 studs and another 12 1x1 round tiles, and these are far from the only 1x1 bricks used in this set. On the bright side, with all these small pieces you get somewhere in the ballpark of 20 extra bricks. As for the rest of the bricks, there is nothing too exciting, but you really can’t expect much from a set like this. The only major problem with the parts is like others said, the white bricks are slightly yellowed, with slightly being the key word here. I don’t understand this since my Classic Space sets from my childhood have no yellowing at all. However, since the slight yellowing varies, the VIP card doesn’t look like the single solid color that it should be. The store however looks fine as there are plenty of colored details to break up its monotonous walls.

The set has two separate components that may be combined together. A small Lego store, and a VIP card. Both of which feature technic holes on either side allowing you to connect them however you please, or not at all. However I do think the suggested way of connecting them looks best.

The Lego store is small but surprisingly accurate. It only has 2 walls, which allows you easy access to the interior, but includes every major feature. On one wall you see the various Lego sets for sale, all of which are created by stickers. The other is the pick a brick wall which looks fantastic. In front of the pick a brick wall is the cash register and in front of that is a little box resembling where they sell accessories and where they have loose bricks to play with. On the wall of sets there is strangely a mug which seems very out of place, especially since it is another mug that is accurately used to represent accessories in the middle of the store. Then there is the dragon which slithers it’s way along both sides of the wall. While it is very simple, it is also highly recognizable as a Chinese style dragon and does a great job representing the life sized Lego builds found in Lego stores. The store features a mostly tiled floor, but with a few studs to hold minifigures. The minifigure who represents an employee looks rather generic except for the large Lego logo on the back of his shirt which makes him a pretty cool minifigure to have. He carries a Lego case, which seems a little strange, I think a minifigure statue would have been more fun and more appropriate, but not a big deal.

The VIP card isn’t nearly as exciting, it’s an even simpler build and of course is relatively flat. It does look nice however, and the solid red minifigure representing the I is a nice touch. Thanks to the minifigure, I kind of feel like this can represent a wall on the exterior of a Lego store. It is for this reason that I find it appropriate to attach the two builds. But clearly this is a secondary build and not the reason why you should be getting this set. 

Overall, this isn’t a set that you need to have, but it is very cute. If you have kids who enjoy going to Lego stores, then it is a very nice representation of a place that you no doubt spend a lot of time in in the real world. Sure, you could easily design a larger Lego store with spare bricks, but I’m not sure that is really necessary, this set is more than sufficient in representing all of the features of a store. It is the stickers that make this set, so if you are opposed to stickers you may not want it. However, given how few points it costs, if you will be ordering from Lego online, then getting this set is a no brainer!
